text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 2440 or fax your request to (361) 351 7141.
ALL PAPERS

- The government will decide on the extent of energy price hikes today. A meeting was held on Wednesday with representatives of the government, Hungarian energy sector and foreign investors. Nepszava reports that investors rejected the suggested figures, saying that they do not allow for their their eight percent profit margin.
- Prime Minister Gyula Horn met Polish Catholic Archbishop Jozef Glemp in Warsaw on Wednesday.
- Free Democrat President Ivan Peto said on Wednesday that the upcoming weekend congress of his party should aim chiefly to discuss future plans rather than the question of coalition cooperation.
- The Democratic Federation of Hungarians in Romania will take part in upcoming coalition negotiations.

- The tax authority APEH will call on private entrepreneurs with a declared annual income below a certain limit to amend their declarations, while in some cases the authority will estimate the tax base itself, said Peter Csobanczy, deputy state secretary at the Ministry of Finance.
- The National Radio and Television Authority is inviting bids for the purchase of Hungarian Television's TV2 and a third national terrestrial channel.

- The mandate of the present general director of the Hungarian News Agency MTI expires this week and no successor has yet been designated, although Jozsef Meruk, campaign chief of the Socialist Party in 1990, is reportedly slated for appointment as MTI chief.
MAGYAR NEMZET

- Hans van de Broek, the official responsible for external relations at the European Commission, told a two-day session of the EU Hungarian associate parliamentary committee in Brussels that the Hungarian economy, thanks to the government's stabilisation programme, has made major headway.
NEPSZABADSAG

- Defence Minister Gyorgy Keleti told a joint meeting of Parliament's foreign and defence committees Wednesday that unspecified NATO officials had sent out feelers to discern whether Hungary wishes to take part in the SFOR mission to be set up as a successor to IFOR.
- The food, beverage and food processing exhibition was opened at Kobanya fair ground on Wednesday.
NAPI GAZDASAG
- Imports in the first nine months of 1996 totalled HUF 1,755.8 billion, while a total of HUF 1,408.5 billion was exported by Hungary.

- EBRD is to grant a loan of ECU 120 million and EIB ECU 100 million toward restructuring of the Hungarian Railways. MAV would receive an additional ECU 80 million in the form of non-refundable financial aid from PHARE.
- The Local Council of Tiszaujvaros has sold its 10.5 percent stake in Tiszai Vegyi Kombinat on the OTC market.
MAGYAR HIRLAP
- Dunaholding closed the first nine months of the year with losses of HUF 1.1 billion.

- Poverty has assumed such proportions in Hungary that it can no longer be guaranteed a hunger revolt will not break out, said Florian Farkas, chairman of the National Gypsy Minority Local Government at a meeting held this week.

- The general secretary of the Business Software Alliance, the international organisation formed to curb the trade and use of illegal software, said on Wednesday that 75 percent of the software in use in Hungary is counterfeit.
-- Budapest newsroom (36-1) 327 4040
